entry.title: Re: Step-by-Step Guide to SOAP Integration in SAP CPI
entry.content:
Hi @dennis_luce1 

Steps to Specify SOAP Action in CPI's SOAP Receiver Adapt

Open the Integration Flow: Navigate to your integration flow in SAP CPI.

Access the SOAP Receiver Adapter: Double-click on the SOAP receiver adapter connected to your external system.

Configure the Connection Tab: In the adapter's configuration window, go to the "Connection" tab.

Specify SOAP Action: Locate the "SOAP Action" field. This is where you enter the specific SOAP action value required by the target web service. The SOAP Action typically represents the operation or method you intend to invoke on the target service.

Finding the Correct SOAP Action: The correct SOAP Action value can usually be found in the WSDL (Web Services Description Language) file provided by the external web service. Look for the soapAction attribute within the soap:operation element of the relevant operation you are calling.

entry.title: Two-Tier ERP - Cloud ERP Release 2508
entry.content:
We’re excited to share the latest scenarios as part of Two-Tier ERP strategy with the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 release. With these new additions, two-tier ERP continues to empower organizations with scalable, agile, and cost-effective ERP solutions that seamlessly integrate headquarters and subsidiaries across diverse business scenarios.

      

Let's go through the highlights of the new innovative scenarios from the space of Supply chain planning, Plant maintenance and Finance which are relevant for the large enterprises with Discrete Industry.

Integrated Business Planning with IBP 

This scenario enables synchronized demand planning between Headquarters and subsidiaries using historical sales data, statistical forecasting, and real-time collaboration to optimize the consolidated plan for procurement and inventory management from the headquarters. IBP uses the historical sales orders data from both the headquarters and subsidiaries and generates statistical forecasted demand based on various forecasting algorithms. The planners in subsidiaries can adjust this local forecasted demand based on special events, promotions etc. and generate a final consensus demand which is then translated to headquarters as Planned Independent Requirements (PIRs) for centralized procurement/production.

 

For details Please refer to the blog post written by my colleagues Kavyanshi and Kangkana:   Two- Tier ERP: Demand Planning with SAP IBP for Headquarter - Subsidiary model

Equipment Refurbishment with Sales & Services Integration 

Two-Tier ERP solution for the process of Equipment Refurbishment with sales & services integration. The two scenarios support seamless refurbishment workflows for leased or rented equipment across Headquarters and subsidiaries, ensuring efficient maintenance, asset tracking, and customer service.  Here are the two possible use cases, 

Scenario 1: Headquarters leases out a high value equipment to the subsidiary on lease basis for a particular time with subsidiary paying monthly rents and spending on equipment maintenance. There is an equivalent lease-in contract at the subsidiary with automatic creation of asset master and manual creation of Equipment master. During Asset maintenance in case the equipment needs refurbishment, it is sent to headquarters for Refurbishment. 

 

Scenario 2: customer places a contract with the subsidiary for an equipment. Equipment is delivered to the customer as a consignment and updated in master as equipment at customer location. The parameters or indicators are maintained in the equipment master. The subsidiary is informed of the repair or service required with the customer and equipment details. Monthly rentals are charged against the contracts for the period equipment is at customer location. Between the customer and subsidiary, vendor invoicing is done for the service or repair carried out on the equipment. The subsidiary decides if the equipment needs repair or refurbishment during annual equipment maintenance through service order. In case of repair, in-house repair is carried out at subsidiary and in case of refurbishment, the damaged equipment is sent to headquarters for Refurbishment with headquarters sending the replaced equipment back to customer via subsidiary. 

 

Please refer to the blogpost written by my colleague Vijayalaxmi : Two-Tier: Refurbishment with Service - SAP Community

Building a Treasury Workstation 

This feature brings in multiple Innovations in Cash and Liquidity Management ensure smooth operation of a treasury workstation in a distributed system environment, enabling data workflows between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private /ECC systems, including Bank Account Management, Cash-Flow and TRM accounting documents.   

   

                                              

Capabilities

  • Two-tier treasury management: accounting document integration routing
  • Bank account unique IDs for cross-system management
  • More Forecasted Flows Supported for Cash-Flow Reconciliation with End-of-Day Bank Statements

​Value Proposition

  • Streamlined operations
  • Improved data traceability and reliability
  • Safeguarded scenarios where the treasury workstation assumes the role of single source of truth for bank account master data
  • Reduced implementation efforts and operational costs for customers and partners who deploy treasury management in the cloud system
  • Enhanced Cash-Flow Replication: both push and pull features are enabled for cash flow replication         

If you are interested in the latest and greatest blog posts on Two-Tier ERP, please take a look at the Community page for      Two-Tier ERP.

Watch the Replays of Our SAP Cloud ERP 2508 Early Release Series!   

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand – anywhere, anytime.

entry.title: SAP Activate for SAP BTP : End-to-End Guidance for SAP Integration Suite - Now with Joule!
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce a major enhancement to the SAP Activate Roadmap for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) - it now includes end-to-end guidance for implementing SAP Integration Suite capabilities.

This update brings clear, actionable direction for managing integration projects from start to finish. Even better, the content is aligned with SAP’s Integration Solution Advisory Methodology (ISA-M) - SAP’s strategic framework for building and managing enterprise integration effectively.

And now, with the integration of Joule, accessing and consuming roadmap content has become an even more intelligent and user-friendly experience.

What’s New

With this roadmap expansion, organizations gain structured guidance to plan, implement, and govern their integration architecture on SAP BTP. This includes support for both new integrations and migration from legacy solutions - all while applying best practices from ISA-M.

Whether you're beginning your cloud journey or optimizing existing integrations, this content helps you move forward with clarity, governance, and agility.

Why It Matters

In today’s complex landscapes, integration is critical — and often underestimated. The enhanced roadmap supports integration leaders, enterprise architects, and project teams with a structured, phase-by-phase approach to reduce risk, align teams, and accelerate outcomes.

By embedding ISA-M principles throughout each phase, the roadmap ensures that integration strategy remains aligned with business priorities, clean core principles, and SAP’s reference architectures.

Updated SAP Activate for SAP BTP Phases with Integration Content:

Discover
Define your integration vision and scope, aligning business needs with strategic planning. Set the stage for a structured integration journey.

Prepare
Establish governance, form key teams, enable stakeholders, and assess your current integration landscape. Lay the technical and organizational groundwork.

Explore
Set up the SAP BTP environment and activate Integration Suite. Design your integration architecture, Define Best Practices, and prepare for testing.

Realize
Develop and migrate integrations, implement DevOps and transport processes, and run detailed testing. Prepare for cutover and operations support.

Deploy
Go live with the SAP BTP solution, execute cutover plans, and transition to support. Resolve outstanding issues for a stable launch.

Run
Operate your solution efficiently and continuously improve. Leverage SAP BTP and Integration Suite innovations to evolve with business needs.

Joule: An Intelligent Way to Access SAP Activate

To make the roadmap even more accessible, SAP Activate for SAP BTP now includes Joule - a digital copilot embedded into SAP’s ecosystem. Joule enables users to engage with Activate content in a natural, intuitive way, offering real-time answers and guidance tailored to your role and project needs.

No more digging through documents or searching manually. With Joule, you can simply ask a question and receive contextual, task-specific support — helping you navigate complex projects with greater ease and confidence.

Joule brings a more intelligent experience to SAP Activate, empowering teams to make better decisions, faster. Watch the video below to learn how to access Joule from within SAP Activate Roadmap for SAP Business Technology Platform

  

 You can access this enhanced content now in the SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer, under SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform. Whether you’re building new integrations or optimizing existing ones, and whether your environment is cloud, hybrid, or multi-cloud — this roadmap supported by Joule, helps ensure your success.

Keep the Feedback Coming 

We continue to gather feedback from our own customer community, our SAP experts, and partners, and we follow an agile methodology to build on the previous version and continuously improve the content.

In the past, your feedback has driven meaningful improvements. Whether it was simplifying navigation, creating new tasks, or updating accelerators, your input has helped us focus on what truly matters to you, during your implementation journey.  You can help us improve by providing feedback in the following ways 

  1. You can provide feedback directly in road map viewer while viewing the content. Refer to the blog Providing Feedback in SAP Activate road map viewer.
  2. Send us a direct email via: sapactivate@sap.com
  3. Leave us your comments in the section below.
Thank you for your continued engagement with SAP Activate!

entry.title: How to Trigger notification to HR team after all Onb tasks are completed (not just compliance)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m looking for guidance on setting up a notification in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding 2.0.

Currently, we have a notification configured that triggers once compliance tasks are completed. However, there are additional onboarding steps that must be completed before the HR Services team can proceed with hiring the candidate in the system (from Manage Pending Hire).

The issue is:
The current notification triggers too early, right after compliance step is completed , even though other required tasks are still pending.

Goal: Trigger a notification to the HR Services team only after all onboarding tasks (standard + custom) are completed, not just compliance. ( even if the record moves to manage pending hire)

Proposed Approach:

  1. Create a separate email category with an explicit recipient (HR Services email ID, not role-based).
  2. Configure a trigger for that email category.
  3. Create a new email template for the notification.
  4. Should I use a business rule to ensure the notification only goes when all required tasks are marked as complete? and do i need to disable the current email template that is used for notifying HR services once compliance task is completed?)

Questions:

  1. Is this the correct approach?
  2. Has anyone implemented a similar setup?
  3. Can business rules be used to check the status of all onboarding tasks (including custom ones) before sending a notification?

Appreciate any insights or recommendations, thanks in advance!

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud : SAP Databricks のプロビジョニング
entry.content:
本ブログはSAP Business Data Cloud(SAP BDC)のプロビジョニング方法についてガイドします。
※本ブログの原文はこちらです。また、最新アップデート情報の確認のために、併せてSAP BDCのマニュアルもご確認ください。

このシリーズは、次の 5 つブログで構成されます。

Part 1: SAP for Me によるSAP BDCのプロビジョニング
Part 2: SAP Datasphere のプロビジョニング
Part 3: SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング
Part 4: SAP Databricks のプロビジョニング
Part 5: Intelligent Applications と Data Packages のインストール

今回は、「Part 4: SAP Databricks のプロビジョニング」です。

 

Part 4: SAP Databricks のプロビジョニング

本ブログでは、Business Data Cloud Core を介して SAP Databricksをプロビジョニングする方法について説明します。

  1. SAP DatasphereとSAP Analytics Cloudのプロビジョニングが完了するとSAP Databricksを開始できます(順序は問いません)。

     

  2. 表示される「SAP Databricksのプロビジョニング」ダイアログで、ソリューション名、リソースグループ、ビジネスタイプなどの詳細情報を入力します。ビジネスタイプは「テスト」または「本番」から選択できます。

     

  3. クォータ量は正確な数量を入力する必要はありません。SAP Databricksは、キャパシティユニットを指定しなくてもご利用いただけます。課金は指定されたクォータではなく、SAP Databricksの実際の使用量に基づいて行われます。「1」を選択して次のステップに進んでください。

     

  4. SAP Databricks と統合する既存のランドスケープから IAS (Identity Authentication Service) を選択します。

     

  5. 設定パラメータセクションで、所有者のメールアドレス、名前などの詳細を入力します。BDCコックピットのプロビジョニングに以前選択した同じ地域(リージョン)を選択します。
  6. SAP Databricksでは、SAP Databricksテナントはアカウントの形で実装されます。アカウント名を入力してください。リソース名も使用できます。複数のSAP Databricksアカウントがある場合は、区別しやすい名前を使用してください。

     

  7. SAP Databricksテナントを追加するフォーメーションを選択します。前のタブで選択したSAP DatabricksテナントとIASシステムを含むフォーメーションの名前を入力します。別のステップで、SAP Databricksとその他のSAP Business Data Cloudシステムを含む「Business Data Cloud」タイプのフォーメーションを作成します。「SAP Business Data Cloudのプロビジョニング入門ガイド」を参照する か、このDatabricksテナントを他のBDCアプリケーションを含む既存のフォーメーションに追加します。
     
  8. プロビジョニングリクエストが送信されたことを通知する確認メッセージが表示されます。「リソースで表示」をクリックすると、指定されたリソースグループ内のテナントが表示されます。
  9. リソースタブでは、ソリューションのステータスは「処理中」です。右側のペインで、ソリューションの下にあるテナントをクリックして詳細ビューを開きます。

     

  10. テナントの詳細ビューの上部にある「詳細の表示」リンクをクリックします。SAP Databricksアカウントへのアクティベーションリンクを提供するポップアップウィンドウが開きます。SAP Databricksテナントの所有者として定義されている場合は、このリンクをクリックしてSAP Databricks のアクティベーションフローを完了してください（下記の「SAP Databricksアカウントのアクティベーション」を参照）。そうでない場合は、アクティベーションリンクをSAP Databricksの所有者と共有し、アクティベーションフローを完了するよう依頼してください。
  11. アカウントが有効化されると、SAP for Meで、 SAP Databricksソリューションとテナントのステータスが「準備完了」に変わります。SAP Databricksテナントの詳細ビューの「パス」フィールドで、URL をクリックしてSAP Databricksテナントを開き、アカウントにログインします。
  12. プロビジョニング中に指定されたSAP Databricksのシステム所有者は、テナントがプロビジョニングされると電子メール通知を受け取ります。
  13. テナントの準備ができたら、「リソース」タブの下のリンクとテナントの詳細からテナントにアクセスできるようになります。
  14. 「顧客ランドスケープ」では、新しいテナントのシステムの詳細を確認できます。また、システム統合が視覚的に表示されるため、システムランドスケープの理解と操作が容易になります。
  15. 次のステップとして、既に作成してあるBDCテナントを追加した「フォーメーション」にテナントを追加する必要があります。
  16. 製品とポートフォリオ > Business Data Cloud > 顧客ランドスケープ > フォーメーションに移動します。
  17. 正しいフォーメーションを選択し、「システムを含める」をクリックして、フォーメーションに含めるSAP Databricksテナントを選択し、変更を保存します。

 

SAP Databricksアカウントの有効化

SAP Databricks アカウントは、指定された SAP Databricks 所有者によってアクティベートされます。所有者であるものの、SAP for Me 経由で SAP Databricks ソリューションをまだプロビジョニングしていない場合は、指定されたユーザーからアクティベーションリンクが送信されます。

  1. リンクをクリックすると、SAP Databricksテナントにリダイレクトされます。「続行」をクリックしてサインアッププロセスに進みます。
  2. SAP Databricksのプライバシー設定センターが開くので、ご希望のCookieを選択し、「続行」をクリックしてください。
  3. プロビジョニング中に指定したアドレスに、Databricks からワンタイム コードを含む電子メールが届きます。表示される確認画面にこのコードを入力してください。
  4. 次のページで利用規約に同意します。これらの手順を完了すると、「プロビジョニングが完了しました」というメッセージが表示され、SAP Databricksアカウントのプロビジョニングが正常に完了したことがわかります。

SAP for Me を通じて SAP Databricks テナントをプロビジョニングし、オーナー ロールを持つユーザーとして SAP Databricks アカウントをアクティブ化すると、このユーザーはメイン URL 経由でログインしてテナントにアクセスできるようになります。これにより、選択した SAP Databricks ワークスペースへのエントリが許可されます。

これで、BDC Core内でSAP Databricksが正常にプロビジョニングされました。

※ このブログの原文を書いてくれたShreyasri Boseに感謝します。

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Number Prefixing
entry.content:
Yes possible to have different number ranges

Go to SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Order → Define Document Types. Create document types like:

  • NB for standard POs
  • ZNS for non-stock items
  • ZSRV for services

Go to T-code OMH6 or follow the path SPRO → MM → Purchasing → Purchase Order → Define Number Ranges. Assign each number range to the corresponding document type.

For MRP-generated POs, configure the system to use the correct document type via SPRO → Production Planning → MRP → Define Document Type for Purchase Requisitions and Orders

entry.title: Unravelling the ‘technical user’ propagation scenarios in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

When it comes to securely connecting to SAP on-premise systems, API Management and Cloud Integration stand as two key pillars of the SAP Integration Suite. While API Management is often aligned with user-centric flows — where the focus is on authenticating and authorizing the end user — Cloud Integration has traditionally dealt with system-to-system communication, which involves backend calls without direct end-user context.

Having said that, across both these capabilities, the ability to connect to backend systems using a fixed technical credential is a widely desired * approach. However, in many SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) scenarios, the term technical user is often equated with “Basic Authentication” — a method increasingly viewed by organizations as less secure. A stronger and more trusted approach for connecting applications and services running in SAP BTP to SAP on-premise systems is principal propagation, where the SAP Cloud Connector generates a short-lived X.509 certificate containing a Common Name (CN) dynamically retrieved from the calling system.

💡 * CPI customers on the BTP Neo environment are familiar with a feature called certificate-to-user mapping, which allows an incoming client certificate to be directly mapped to a backend user identity. This made technical user propagation both straightforward and widely adopted.

In Cloud Foundry, the incoming certificate is typically mapped to an access token associated with the service key credential rather than being directly mapped to a backend user's security context, as in Neo. As a result, customers often struggle to replicate their established Neo patterns, especially for fixed technical identities — this is the exact problem that has now been solved!

As a side note, if you’d like to dive deeper into certificate-to-user mapping and certificate-based authentication in SAP Cloud Integration, you can refer to Mandy Krimmel’s insightful blog posts covering both Neo and Cloud Foundry.

Here's where things start to get interesting. With Cloud Connector version 2.15, SAP introduced the ability to perform technical user propagation using the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication HTTP header. This allows a cloud application to send a signed JWT representing the fixed technical identity, which the Cloud Connector uses to generate a short-lived X.509 certificate — all without relying on static passwords. You can read more about this feature in the official SAP Help Portal documentation and the SAP Community blog post.

Traditionally, principal propagation has been used to propagate an end-user identity, but here’s the beauty: it can just as easily propagate a fixed (technical) identity as a short-lived X.509 certificate. This means you can retain all the advantages of principal propagation — dynamic credentials, reduced exposure, and assured identity mapping — without falling back to basic authentication.

 

This blog post, co-authored by Vinayak Adkoli and Sunny Kapoor, focuses on technical user propagation within Cloud Integration, exploring how such credentials can be securely propagated across three common Receiver Adapters — SOAP, HTTP, and OData V2. In a follow-up post, we will examine similar patterns from the perspective of API Management’s OnPremise connectivity flows.

2. Cloud Connector and backend prerequisites to support Technical user propagation

Before you can configure an IFlow in SAP Integration Suite to propagate a fixed technical user via a short-lived X.509 certificate, both the SAP Cloud Connector and the backend system must be prepared to handle this scenario.

This section outlines the key steps and underlying rationale, but it is not a complete how-to guide. For detailed, step-by-step instructions, please refer to the resources listed below.

  • Product documentation - always up-to-date with the latest enhancements.
  • Michael's blog. A little old, but still relevant.
  • Martin Raepple's blog is an excellent resource for a step-by-step procedure.

📢  (tip) Because the screenshots are embedded within a table, they may appear small even when opened in a new window. To view them in a larger size, simply change the image URL from '.../medium' to '.../large'

 

Step No.

Description

Screenshot

1.

Let's begin the setup by reviewing the SAP Cloud Connector Configuration page.

In the Configuration -> On-Premise section of the Cloud Connector, make sure you have a System Certificate populated with an intermediate CA certificate.

2.

Likewise, the same certificate is also included in the CA Certificate section.

IMP: Note that within the Principal Propagation section, the subject pattern has been specified as CN={$name}. 

It is also possible to create multiple rules that resolve based on a condition. For example, if the system sees an 'email' claim in the token, it will use the email attribute to construct the subject pattern.

You can read more about the order of resolution of subject patterns here.

3.

In the Access Control section of the Connector settings, be sure to set the Protocol to ‘HTTPS’ and the Principal Type to ‘X.509’.

💡Note that I've unchecked the option to use 'System Certificate for Logon'. This is a nuance that we will call out separately in section 6

4.Let's look at our backend configurations now. Txn STRUST leads us to the Trust Manager. I have the CA certificate and the Root Certificate that signed this CA certificate in the Trust Store
5.Note that there are 3 key configuration parameters defined in Txn RZ10. The ICM node will need to be restarted after this.
6.

This is one of the most important steps. Transaction CERTRULE opens the rule-based certificate mapping screen. If you've previously set up principal propagation, you likely already have a rule using the 'CN=*' filter, where the wildcard typically resolves to an email address or user name. This approach works well for user-based principal propagation. However, since our objective here is to propagate a technical user, we'll instead make use of the Explicit Mapping tab. We’ll go into more detail on this in section 5.

💡You will notice that I’ve taken a slightly different approach here compared to Munish Suri’s helpful blog, where he creates a service user in transaction SU01. The reason that step won’t work in our case is that the ‘alias’ field is limited to 40 characters, while the client ID from BTP XSUAA exceeds that limit.

 

3. SAP Integration Suite / Cloud Integration settings to support Technical user propagation

The table below highlights the key settings we’ll be using on the SAP Integration Suite side.

 

Step No.

Description

Screenshot

1.

Since we’ve touched on the ‘certificate-to-user’ mapping functionality in Neo, let’s align our setup in the Integration Suite tenant with that behavior. 

Make sure you have generated a service key for the 'Integration-Flow' service plan of the Process Integration Runtime service instance. Select either the 'Certificate' or 'External Certificate' option from the drop-down while doing so. 

2.

If you select ‘Certificate’, the BTP platform will generate the certificate and key in PEM format, which will be displayed on the next screen for you to copy.

Make a note of the client_id to be used at a later step. 

3.Pro Tip: Since the certificate attribute contains a newline character (\n), you will need to remove it before attempting to generate a PFX file or any other format that can encode the key and certificate together, using tools like OpenSSL. Here is a quick video demonstration that can eliminate all newline characters in one go from Sublime Text. (Do a 'Find All' of \n and hit 'enter' to remove them)
4.

In addition to a service key corresponding to 'Certificate', make sure you have one with 'client credentials' as well. This will be used to demonstrate the scenario where just the 'client credential' will be propagated as a 'technical principal. Impressive, huh 😎

Make a note of the client_id to be used at a later step. 

4. Setting up a simple IFlow for Technical user propagation

To illustrate how technical user propagation works in practice, we’ll walk through the setup of three simple integration flows (iFlows) in SAP Cloud Integration — each using a different Receiver Adapter: SOAP, HTTP, and OData V2. These examples are deliberately kept minimal so you can focus on the adapter configuration and principal propagation setup, without getting lost in unrelated processing logic. 

Spoiler
Technical user propagation for HTTP and OData V2 Adapters works out of the box.  A small adjustment is needed only for the SOAP Adapter.

As mentioned before, each scenario we present can be executed in either of the two ways as listed below to inject the fixed technical identity :

  • With a client certificate presented by the sending system (i.e. mTLS)
  • Following 'client credential' grant type, i.e., client_id and client_secret

4.1. OData V2 Receiver Adapter – Technical user propagation setup

Let’s start with a common integration scenario: consuming an OData V2 service from an on-premise SAP backend system. In this setup, technical user propagation enables Cloud Integration to connect to the backend using a short-lived X.509 certificate that represents a fixed technical identity.

With the 2506 update, SAP Integration Suite now supports technical user propagation out of the box. Just choose ‘principal propagation’ in the Authentication drop-down, and the system will automatically pass along either the end-user or technical-user context to the cloud connector and eventually to the backend. 

2506 product increment

Below is an illustration of a simple IFlow that leverages the OData V2 receiver adapter

 

a simplified example of an OData V2 Receiver Adapter

Let's review the 'Connection' settings on the Adapter's property sheet. You will notice that I've set the 'Authentication' to Principal Propagation.

property sheet of the OData Receiver

So far, everything looks good. The next step is to map the technical client identifier to a backend user—a process we’ll walk through in detail in section 5.

 

⚠️Make sure you refer to that section before continuing further. 

Invoking a curl command by injecting a client certificate (note that the private key and certificate were available during step 3.2):

curl --cert mycertificate.pem --key pvtkey.key  --header 'target: odata' https://<cpi-instance>.cfapps.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/http/<pathsuffix>

If you’d rather use a tool like Postman or Bruno instead of curl, ensure you have the client certificate in PFX format so it can be attached to your requests.

Client Certificate available in Postman

Client Certificate available in Bruno

✅A successful execution should retrieve the needed results from the backend.

Let’s review key log entries from both SAP Cloud Connector and the backend system to illustrate how technical user propagation was performed.

In the screenshot below from the ljs_trace file in SAP Cloud Connector, the first highlighted entry shows the claims extracted from the decoded JWT received from Cloud Integration. The second entry confirms that the principal was resolved to type Technical, as outlined in step 5.1.

Next, you can see that an X.509 certificate was generated with the Common Name (CN) set to the technical identifier.

In the ‘Monitor’ perspective, you can see the technical identifier listed under the ‘User’ section, confirming that it was successfully propagated to the backend.

Here is a log entry from the ICM node in the backend confirming that the certificate subject for the said technical identifier was received.

Finally, based on the rule set in the CERTRULE, you can verify that the subject. from the certificate resolves to the backend user (uname) called 'SUITEUSER'.  This concludes one end-to-end cycle. 

 

4.2. HTTP Receiver Adapter – Technical user propagation setup

After exploring the OData V2 adapter, let’s look at the HTTP Receiver Adapter scenario, which is used when connecting to custom REST APIs / generically available HTTP endpoints in the backend system.

The good news here is that this scenario also works in a manner very similar to the one described above. Here is a snippet of the documentation page that describes the support for technical user propagation.

Let's extend our sample IFlow with a sequence of steps that leverages this functionality.

I've marked the HTTP Receiver Adapter attached to a new 'Request-Reply' step. The adapter’s property sheet closely resembles that of the OData V2 Adapter, with the authentication type configured as Principal Propagation.

Let’s trigger the IFlow using a curl command. Unlike the OData V2 Adapter example, where we used a certificate, this time we’ll authenticate with the client_credentials grant type by providing a Bearer token.

curl --header 'Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciO<truncated>' https://<cpi-instance>.cfapps.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/http/<pathsuffix>

✅You should see a successful execution, and the Cloud Connector and backend logs should align with the explanation in the OData V2 Adapter scenario. 

4.3. SOAP Receiver Adapter – Technical user propagation setup

Next, let’s set up the same scenario for the SOAP Receiver Adapter. Unlike the HTTP and OData V2 adapters, which worked almost seamlessly by simply enabling ‘principal propagation,’ the SOAP approach requires a bit more configuration effort.  (Note that this may change in one of our future releases.)

Here is my updated sample IFlow with a local integration process step added to handle the SOAP Adapter as well.

The first step in my Local Integration Process is a Content Modifier that creates the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header and assigns it the value of the incoming 'Authorization' header.

Here is a simple illustration of my SOAP Adapter that invokes a SOAP Service from my S/4HANA system. Carefully note that I have set the 'Authentication' to none (instead of principal propagation).  

Also, do not forget to include the 'Authorization' as an allowed header within the Runtime Configuration section block, as we are reading this attribute. You may need to tailor the Namespace Mapping based on your backend's WSDL settings.

 

Let's go ahead and issue a POST call to our Integration Flow to invoke the 'CreditManagementAccountByIDQuery' Operation from the SOAP Service.

Here is the (request.xml) XML payload I've used:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<glob:CreditManagementAccountByIDQuery xmlns:glob="http://sap.com/xi/SAPGlobal/Global">
  <Selection>
    <DebtorPartyInternalID>MDG_CU01</DebtorPartyInternalID>
    <CreditsegmentInternalID>0002</CreditsegmentInternalID>
  </Selection>
  <LanguageCode>en</LanguageCode>
</glob:CreditManagementAccountByIDQuery>

Here are my CURL commands:

echo "eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsImprd...full_token_here...JJQog" > token.txt
TOKEN=$(cat token.txt)
curl 'https://<cpi-instance>.cfapps.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/http/<pathsuffix>' \
  --header 'target: soap' \
  --header 'Content-Type: text/xml; charset=utf-8' \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
  --data .xml

This concludes our testing of invoking the SOAP Adapter.

💡A Note on Transparency in Technical User Propagation

In the three scenarios we laid out above (OData V2, SOAP, and HTTP), the client or sender system was responsible for presenting the technical client ID that ultimately got propagated downstream. While this approach works well, there are situations where it may be desirable to keep this entire process transparent to the end user.

In such cases, the integration developer can insert a Request Reply step in the iFlow to first call the OAuth token endpoint using a different set of credentials — not necessarily exposed or known to the consuming client. The resulting access token can then be injected into the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication header, ensuring that the technical user propagation still takes place, but without burdening the client with the responsibility of handling technical credentials directly. Here is a sample Groovy script snippet that can be placed after retrieving the access token

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get the response body as a string
    def body = message.getBody(String);
    
    // Parse the JSON response
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper();
    def jsonResponse = jsonSlurper.parseText(body);
    
    // Extract the access token (assuming the token is in a field called "access_token")
    def accessToken = jsonResponse.access_token;
    def bearerToken = "Bearer "+ accessToken;
    
    // Set the access token as a message header for technical authentication
    message.setHeader("SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication", bearerToken);
    
    return message;
}

This pattern is particularly useful when you want to decouple client-facing authentication from backend technical connectivity, giving you more flexibility and control over how identities are managed across the landscape.

5. Mapping technical users to ABAP users in the backend

Now we will connect the dots between the technical user and an ABAP backend user. This ensures that when Cloud Integration presents the technical identity, the backend system knows exactly which user account to log on with.

We’ll achieve this by generating a sample X.509 certificate that represents the technical client identifier, and then explicitly mapping it to an ABAP user via transaction CERTRULE.

Here is a step-by-step instruction to perform this mapping.

Step No.

Description

Screenshot

1.

Get back to the SAP Cloud Connector -> Configuration -> On Premise setting page and click on the button at the bottom of the screen labelled 'Generate a Sample Certificate'. 

We need this dummy short-lived X.509 certificate to perform the mapping step. 

Notice that I'm demonstrating setting the ${user_type} to 'Technical' as indicated in point 2.2

2.Paste the client_id retrieved from step 3.2 / 3.4 in the CN field and click 'Generate'. This will export a certificate file to your local hard drive.
3.

In your SAP Logon, head to txn  CERTRULE -> Explicit Mappings and import this short-lived certificate from the previous step.

💡Refer back to step 1.6 for an explanation of why this step is needed.

4.

Once the certificate is loaded, click on 'Explicit Mapping' to map the certificate subject to an actual ABAP user / technical alias.

5.

In my screenshot, I'll be mapping the certificate subject to a 'dialog' user. Instead, you can also choose a technical alias.

Your backend service call will be executed in this user's context. 

In ABAP terminology, this corresponds to the sy-uname attribute.

6.If you managed to get this far, you should see an entry created in the mapping table 😀

6. ⚠️ A note of caution on the Cloud Connector "system certificate" default

Let’s take a moment to discuss a nuanced behavior we briefly touched on above in point 2.3. In the Cloud Connector configuration, there is an option called “System Certificate for Logon”. When this option is enabled, the Cloud Connector will use its own system certificate to authenticate in cases where no principal information is available in the request.

While this might sound convenient, it introduces an important caveat: a fixed technical user will always be propagated — even in scenarios where your design expected to rely on true end-user principal propagation. Instead of failing due to missing identity information, the Cloud Connector silently falls back to the system certificate and logs on with the mapped technical user. Another common case that results in “no principal information” is when the authentication section of the Cloud Integration adapter is set to None — either deliberately for testing, or accidentally left that way during configuration.

This can be problematic in security-sensitive landscapes, because it may unintentionally bypass your intended identity propagation setup. It’s therefore crucial to carefully review whether this setting should be enabled in your environment and confirm that it aligns with your authentication and compliance requirements.

7. Final thoughts

As we’ve seen across the OData V2, SOAP, and HTTP receiver adapters, SAP Integration Suite offers a flexible yet secure way to propagate a technical user without falling back on basic authentication. By leveraging the short-lived X.509 certificates issued through Cloud Connector and carefully configuring the adapter authentication settings, customers can ensure consistent, policy-compliant access to their on-premise systems.

This approach not only modernizes the classic “certificate-to-user mapping” patterns familiar from the Neo environment but also aligns with Cloud Foundry’s service key–based model, giving you the best of both worlds: the security of principal propagation and the practicality of fixed user connectivity where required. With these patterns in hand, you can design integrations that are both secure and operationally simple, while avoiding common pitfalls such as unintended fallbacks or misconfigured authentication.

📌In the next installment of this series, we’ll extend the same concept to API Management, focusing on how technical user propagation works through the On-Premise Proxy component — so stay tuned if you’re interested in applying these patterns beyond Cloud Integration.

entry.title: Re: Sending Customer Invoices to CPI system to Trigger it...
entry.content:
Since you can't create new output types, leverage form template variants to differentiate content and routing:

Use the “Maintain Form Templates” Fiori app to create custom templates for each country/system combination.
Assign country-specific logic in the form template (e.g., include a flag or identifier in the XML payload that CPI can use to route).

Example

You can use the same output type but assign different templates based on country determination rules.

In Output Parameter Determination, configure rules based on:

  • Country of the customer
  • Company code or sales org
  • Business partner groupings

This allows you to assign different form templates and communication arrangements even if the output type remains constant.

In CPI, use the payload content (e.g., country code, form template name, or custom XML tag) to:

  • Route to Pagero or Intrum
  • Apply authentication credentials dynamically
  • Maintain separate iFlows for each system

You can also enrich the payload in CPI using content modifiers or XSLT mappings to ensure the correct format per recipient.

If you need to differentiate logos, footers, or static content create Master Form Templates per system (Pagero vs Intrum) and link them to the Content Form Templates accordingly. This helps maintain visual and structural consistency per recipient.

entry.title: Re: Change Message NO CK383 to error message type when do...
entry.content:
You can explore available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to implement custom validations during costing runs. Look for BAdIs under Product Cost Planning or Material Cost Estimates. If a suitable BAdI exists, you can raise a custom error message when BOM is incomplete.

If BAdIs are insufficient, consider building a custom Fiori app or report that scans materials for BOM completeness, flags or blocks cost estimates before execution and raises user-friendly messages outside the standard costing transaction

In fact, some customers use workflow-based pre-checks or mass validation jobs to ensure BOM completeness before running costing. This avoids relying on message control and fits well within Public Cloud constraints.

entry.title: Re: What I Wish I Knew
entry.content:
When I began my SAP journey, I focused heavily on specific modules and technical areas. But over time, I realized that true mastery comes from understanding how the entire SAP ecosystem works together. Here’s what I wish I had known earlier:

1. SAP Is an Ecosystem, Not Just a Collection of Modules

Early on, I concentrated on one area—security. But SAP is deeply interconnected. Finance, supply chain, HR, analytics, infrastructure, and security all influence each other. Understanding the full landscape helps you design better solutions, anticipate downstream impacts, and communicate more effectively across teams.

2. SAP BASIS Is the Backbone

BASIS isn’t just about system admin—it’s the foundation for everything SAP runs on. From transports and performance tuning to upgrades and system copies, a strong BASIS layer ensures reliability and scalability.

3. Platform Architecture Shapes Everything

Whether you're running SAP on-premise, in the cloud, or on SAP BTP, platform decisions affect integration, security, compliance, and agility. I wish I had appreciated earlier how foundational architecture choices are to long-term success.

4. Security Is a Shared Responsibility

Security doesn’t live in isolation. It’s embedded in infrastructure, development, business processes, and user behavior. Collaborating across BASIS, development, and business teams is essential to build secure and compliant systems.

5. Audit Readiness Is a Daily Discipline

Audits aren’t just annual events—they’re reflections of your daily governance. Building audit readiness into operations through automation, documentation, and proactive monitoring saves time and builds trust.

6. Tools Are Powerful—If Aligned

GRC platforms, monitoring tools, and automation solutions are only effective when they’re tailored to your organization’s processes. I learned that simplicity and alignment often outperform complexity.

7. Documentation Is Your Lifeline

Whether it’s system architecture, change logs, or access provisioning, good documentation is invaluable—especially during audits or system transitions.

Stay Curious & Keep Learning

SAP is constantly evolving. New modules, cloud services, and regulatory requirements emerge regularly. Staying curious and investing in continuous learning has been one of the most rewarding parts of my journey.

entry.title: Re: How to Identify POs at 1st Tag Release (Status 03) in...
entry.content:
If your release strategy uses specific release codes for first-level approval (e.g., R1, A1), you can filter directly on those codes in I_PurchaseOrderReleaseStep.

Alternatitively, use CDS view I_PurchaseOrderReleaseStep. This view provides release step-level data for purchase orders. It includes Purchase Order Number, Release Code, Release Status and Release Date. You can use this view to check if any release step has been completed. Identify which release code was triggered. Filter for POs where first release step is approved, even if overall status is still 03 Combine this with I_PurchaseOrder or I_PurchaseOrderHeader to enrich your report.

entry.title: Skip step in flexible PO workflow
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

We have a requirement to implement Flexible PO approval process. We have a bespoke table with three levels of approval. Therefore, we have written logic in BADI-MMPUR_WORKFLOW_AGENTS_V2 for agent determination. The approval rationale is like below.
Variance  -  difference between the standard price of the material and the item's net price.

If the difference is between 30% and 50%, go to approver 1.
If there is a difference between 50% and 90%, go to approvers 1 and 2.
If GT 90%, go to approvers 1 + 2 + 3.

Three-level approvals are predefined in the Manage Workflows in Purchase Orders steps.

 

We have a scenario where variance is falling between 30-50 which means we will have only 1 level approval.  So when control goes to level 2 , the approvers table will be empty and as agent determination is mandatory the system throws an exception. Ideally when condition is satisfied rest of the steps need to be skipped ( level 2 and 3 in this case ).

Currently we have a condition at workflow level as we need automatic approval if the variance is less than 30%.

Since BADI only allows for one condition ID (SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF), we are unable to add another condition for step-level control.

We are at a standstill and unable to proceed, went through relevant blogs but was unable to find anything.
Has anyone worked on a requirement like this before?

Please let me  if any information is needed further.

Thank you

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: Re: Is B.sc degree enough for ABAP career
entry.content:
Do not spend time in doing another degree at this stage unless you want to switch career.

  1. Deepen Your ABAP Expertise
  • Advanced ABAP: Learn Object-Oriented ABAP, performance tuning, and modularization techniques. ABAP Cloud
  • ABAP on HANA: Understand how to optimize code for HANA using CDS views, AMDP, and HANA-specific SQL.
  • Clean Core Principles: Focus on writing upgrade-safe, extensible code using SAP’s clean core strategy.
  1. Expand into SAP Functional Knowledge
  • Learn how ABAP interacts with modules like FI/CO, MM, SD, and HR.
  • Understanding business processes will help you write more effective and relevant code.
  1. Explore SAP Fiori & UI5
  • Learn SAPUI5, Fiori Elements, and OData services to build modern, user-friendly interfaces.
  • This bridges the gap between backend and frontend development.
  1. Get Familiar with SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform)
  • Explore CAP (Cloud Application Programming) model and SAP BTP services.
  • Learn how to build cloud-native apps and extensions using ABAP in the cloud.

entry.title: Re: Discrepancy in Amount Calculation D
entry.content:
As you know, OB90 is still relevant for defining rounding behavior at the company code level. Ensure, rounding rule is set to match your pricing logic. It aligns with the condition types used in your SD pricing procedure. Routine 17 must be assigned under the Calculation Type field in your pricing procedure;  not under Condition Base Value. Misplacement can cause it to behave like Routine 16. If exact decimal matching is critical (e.g., for GST returns), you can add a manual header condition to adjust the final amount

While I am not sure any enhanced feature is available, the SSCUI improvements make it easier to configure rounding rules, but they don’t change the underlying tax calculation logic. Here's what they do help with Condition Type Rounding Rules (SSCUI 101120)

entry.title: Re: Crystal Report 2016 crashing issue
entry.content:
There can be multiple reasons why Crystal Reports 2016 is crashing. Here are some common causes and solutions that have worked for others in the community:

Common Fixes:

Update to the Latest Patch

Make sure you're on the latest service pack (SP). Older versions of CR 2016 had known stability issues.

Download patches directly from the SAP website: SAP Crystal Reports Downloads

Check .NET Framework

Crystal Reports relies heavily on the .NET Framework. Ensure you're running a compatible version (typically .NET 4.7.2 or later for SP updates).

Reinstall or repair the framework if crashes persist.

Graphics Driver Conflicts

Some users reported crashes related to GPU drivers, especially when rendering previews or exporting reports.

Try updating or rolling back your graphics driver to test.

Corrupt Reports

If only certain reports are crashing, the file itself might be corrupted.

Open the report on another machine to confirm.

Recreate the report from scratch if needed.

Printer Settings

Crystal Reports often references the default printer. A missing or incompatible printer driver can cause crashes.

Try setting a basic printer (like Microsoft Print to PDF) as the default.

User Permissions

Run CR as Administrator to rule out permission issues.

Ensure users have access to temp directories and required registry keys.

Third-Party Add-ons or Anti-Virus

Some plugins or antivirus software interfere with Crystal Reports.

Try disabling AV temporarily or running in Safe Mode.

Logs & Troubleshooting

Check Windows Event Viewer for application crash logs.

Enable Crystal Reports logging (via registry) to trace the source of the issue.

entry.title: Re: user-defined fields blocked/read only SAP BO Purchase...
entry.content:
Hello,

  • Root cause → The Financial Limited license does not allow searching by UDFs in marketing documents (like Purchase Orders). That’s why UDF fields are locked in the Find (binocular) window.

  • Other licenses (Professional or Purchasing Limited) → Can search by UDFs without issue.

  • Why only this user → He’s the only one with Financial Limited, others have higher licenses.

  • Workarounds:

    1. Upgrade license → Assign Purchasing Limited or Professional if UDF search is required.

    2. Use Queries → Create SQL queries for PO search by UDFs and assign them in the Query Manager or add to the main menu.

    3. Formatted Searches / Add-on → For advanced/custom searching if queries aren’t enough.

Regards,

Faraz Maqsud

entry.title: Re: How can I remove the link between an existing product...
entry.content:
Hi @levinefinger ,

Once a Production Order is created from a Sales Order, the link between them cannot be removed, as the OriginEntry and OriginNum fields are read-only.

Possible approaches:

  • Cancel/close the linked Production Order and create a new one manually (without a Sales Order link).

  • For reporting, simply ignore the origin fields or use a UDF to mark orders as needed.

 Unfortunately, the Service Layer does not provide a way to break this link.

Regards,

Faraz Maqsud

entry.title: Re: No matching records found 'G/L Accounts' (OACT) (ODBC...
entry.content:
Dear @nkdashpute ,

Yes, Material Type affects G/L determination if Advanced G/L Determination is active.

For Capital Good (without Fixed Asset Management):

  • Go to Administration → Setup → Financials → G/L Account Determination.

  • Add a rule for Material Type = Capital Good.

  • Map it to a suitable Expense account (Capital Purchases) or an Asset Clearing account.

 Without this mapping, system throws the No matching records found ‘G/L Accounts’ error.

Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Rolling Sum on a Sorted Measure
entry.content:
Hi, Currently this is a limitation in SAC. Running Total does not respect any sort order.

3294430 - Understanding results when applying a Sort to a Running Total Calculation in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) stories - SAP for Me

Excerpts from above note.

Symptom

The Running Total Calculation does not respect sorting order in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

 

Environment

SAP Analytics Cloud 2023.01 and higher

Reproducing the Issue

  1. Create a Story with a Table or Chart widget (for instance dimension as "Product" and measure as "Quantity Sold").
  2. Create a Calculated Measure using Running Total on top of the measure "Quantity Sold". 
 

 

  1. Apply a sort (Ascending/Descending, Highest to Lowest, Custom Sort) on the measure "Quantity Sold".
  2. Notice that the Calculated Measure (Running Total) results become hard to interpret
 

 

Cause

  • This is a by design behavior.
  • In the above example, "Quantity" values have been sorted from highest to lowest, however, the Running Total results reflect the year hierarchy.
  • For example, the running total between 2015 and 2016 is (127+77) = 204, which is correct.

Resolution

  • Running Total results are reflective of the hierarchy order of the dimension and do not reflect the sorting appearance on the front end.
  • For flat dimensions, where no hierarchy exists, results are reflective of the dimension ID ordering within the model.

entry.title: Streamlining REST API Integrations in SAP Datasphere with Task Chains and FastAPI on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction 

With the recent introduction of API Tasks in Task Chains, SAP Datasphere now supports direct orchestration of external REST services (see SAP documentation). This enhancement unlocks new integration possibilities, particularly for scenarios where no standard connectors are available. 

In our use case, we aim to extract data from an open REST API and load it into SAP Datasphere. To achieve this, we developed a custom wrapper API—built with FastAPI and hosted on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)—that handles both data extraction and the writing of that data into SAP HANA Cloud, which underlies SAP Datasphere. The entire data loading process is then triggered and managed via a REST API step within a Task Chain. 

At the core of this solution is a lightweight microservice that seamlessly integrates a third-party REST API into SAP Datasphere. The microservice is designed to be modular, secure, and easy to maintain, and enables a fully automated integration pipeline. 

Key Features of the Approach 

  • REST API extraction wrapped in a FastAPI-based microservice 
  • Basic HTTP Authentication for secure access 
  • Data retrieval from public or external REST APIs 
  • Automatic detection and mapping of SAP HANA-compatible data types 
  • Dynamic table creation in SAP HANA Cloud 
  • Batch data insertion with upload timestamps for traceability 
  • Deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) 
  • Registration as an HTTP connection in SAP Datasphere 
  • Integration into a Task Chain for full orchestration of the data workflow 

 

 

Requirement 

Data integration from 3rd-party REST APIs is still a challenge in SAP Datasphere, particularly when no standard connectors are available. SAP offers solutions like Open Connectors or SAP Cloud Integration via the Integration Suite. However, these options come with additional cost and infrastructure overhead. 

Our proposed solution is a lightweight, developer-friendly alternative that utilizes: 

  • A simple REST service hosted on SAP BTP 
  • Open SQL schema access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance 
  • Integration into Task Chains via the new REST API task type 

This allows full orchestration and governance from within SAP Datasphere, without introducing unnecessary middleware layers. 

Solution 

FastAPI Solution on SAP BTP 

At the core of this architecture lies a microservice built with FastAPI. This Python-based service acts as a universal adapter to extract, transform (lightly), and load data into SAP HANA Cloud. The code can also be found in our GIT repository. 

Key Components 

  1. Authentication 
    All secure endpoints require HTTP Basic Authentication, with credentials configurable via environment variables. 
  2. HANA Integration 
    1. Using the hana_ml library, the service connects to the HANA Cloud database and  
      automatically detects column types using heuristics (e.g., timestamp recognition, length-adjusted NVARCHAR) 
    2. Dynamically creates a table if it doesn't exist 
    3. Inserts records in batch mode, with an added UPLOAD_TS timestamp column 

  3. Endpoints

    Endpoint 

    Method 

    Description 

    / 

    GET 

    Health check 

    /test-hana-connection 

    GET 

    Verifies database credentials and connection 

    /extract-and-write 

    POST 

    Triggers extraction from a third-party API and writes to HANA 

    /preview-data 

    GET 

    Fetches sample records from a REST API 

    /infer-types 

    GET 

    Infers HANA-compatible types from JSON response 

  4. Deployment 
    The service is packaged with a manifest.yaml for deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry). It uses the Python buildpack and runs via uvicorn in production. 
     

Outlook 

This FastAPI-based solution can be flexibly extended to support more advanced integration needs: 

  • Authentication: Easily add OAuth2, API keys, or Bearer tokens to handle secured APIs. 
  • REST Call Chaining: Implement multi-step workflows by chaining dependent API calls asynchronously. 
  • Pagination: Add logic for offset, cursor, or token-based pagination to collect full datasets. 
  • Schema Flexibility: Support field renaming, normalization of nested JSON, and custom type overrides. 

Testing 

For Testing purposes we tested everything with Postman and the public available Harry Potter API https://hp-api.onrender.com. 

SAP Datasphere Integration 

To communicate with this BTP service we performed the following steps: 

  1. Whitelist the IPs of our BTP instance in the SAP Datasphere tenant (For testing from Business Application Studio (BAS)you may also want to whitelist those IPs as well) 
  2. Create a HTTP connection for the usage in the Task Chain 

     

     

In the task chain we can now add this step and configure the body. 

 

 

In the Configuration panel we can now select our HTTP connection: 

 

 

And also configure our REST call: 

After running the Task Chain we can see the data is now loaded into our table. 

 

Conclusion 

The integration of a FastAPI-based microservice into SAP Datasphere via Task Chains marks a significant advancement in streamlining data ingestion from third-party REST APIs. By leveraging SAP BTP for deployment and utilizing the new REST API task type within Task Chains, we demonstrated a lightweight and developer-friendly alternative to traditional integration tools like SAP Cloud Integration or Open Connectors. 

Looking ahead, the framework can be extended to accommodate more complex data workflows, robust security models, and advanced transformation logic. With this foundation, organizations can seamlessly orchestrate external data services within SAP Datasphere while maintaining full control, traceability, and governance—all without the need for additional middleware. 

Links: 

For Integration possibilities with Open Connectors and Fast API deployment you can also take a look at my other blogs 

ZPARTNER Links: 

  • https://www.zpartner.eu/automating-sap-datasphere-task-chains-with-cli-wrapping-fastapi-integration-with-sap-analytics-cloud/ 
  • https://www.zpartner.eu/mastering-custom-integrations-in-sap-datasphere-leveraging-open-connectors-for-rest-apis/ 

SAP Community Links:

entry.title: Re: Bank charges in SAP B1
entry.content:
Hi,

  • Company bears charges → Enter in Bank Charges field. Expense hits Bank Charges G/L.

  • Vendor bears charges → Pay reduced net amount, do not use Bank Charges field. Vendor’s invoice still clears for full amount, but payment sent is less. 

EXAMPLE:-

Company bears charges

Invoice = 10,000
Bank charges = 100

Journal Entry:

  • Dr Vendor 10,000

  • Cr Bank 10,100

  • Dr Bank Charges 100

Vendor gets full 10,000, company books 100 as expense.

Vendor bears charges

Invoice = 10,000
Bank charges = 100

Journal Entry:

  • Dr Vendor 10,000

  • Cr Bank 9,900

  • Cr Vendor (or Adjustment) 100

Vendor receives 9,900, company has no expense.

 

Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Link between OINM Table and Inventory Transfer
entry.content:
Hi,

Yes, OINM rows can be linked to marketing docs via TransType + BaseEntry.
For Inventory Transfer:
• Link OINM.TransType = 67 and OINM.BaseEntry = OWTR.DocEntry.
• Use OWTR.CANCELED = 'N' to exclude canceled transfers.

Example :-

SELECT
OINM.ItemCode,
OINM.Dscription,
OINM.Warehouse,
OINM.InQty,
OINM.OutQty,
OINM.DocDate,
OWTR.DocNum,
OWTR.DocDate AS TransferDate,
OWTR.CANCELED
FROM OINM
INNER JOIN OWTR ON OINM.BaseEntry = OWTR.DocEntry
AND OINM.TransType = 67 
WHERE OWTR.CANCELED = 'N'
ORDER BY OWTR.DocNum, OINM.ItemCode;


Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Why Does SAP B1 Allow Backdated Delivery Without Inve...
entry.content:
Hi,

  • Why deliveries were allowed

    • SAP B1 checks stock at posting time, not by historical date.

    • Because “Allow stock release without item cost” was enabled, the system allowed deliveries even before stock existed.

  • Moving Average calculation

    • Deliveries before GR were posted at cost 0.

    • When GR was posted, system recalculated Moving Average and adjusted COGS via automatic revaluation.

  • Best practices / controls

    • Disable Allow stock release without item cost.

    • Keep Block Negative Inventory active.

    • Lock old posting periods to prevent backdating.

    • Use approvals for deliveries with earlier dates than receipts.

Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Journal Voucher Journal Entry
entry.content:
Hello,

  • Journal Entries are stored in OJDT / JDT1.

  • Journal Vouchers are stored in OJVT / JVT1.

  • To trace: OJDT.BaseRef or OJDT.Ref1 = Journal Voucher number.

  • In the client → open JE → check Remarks/Ref fields to see the voucher number.

Example:-

SELECT
JE.TransId AS JournalEntryID,
JE.Number AS JournalEntryNum,
JE.Ref1 AS Ref1,
JE.Ref2 AS Ref2,
JE.BaseRef AS BaseRef,
JV.TransId AS JVTransId,
JV.Number AS JournalVoucherNum,
JE.Memo AS Remarks,
JE.RefDate AS PostingDate
FROM OJDT JE
LEFT JOIN OJVT JV ON JE.TransId = JV.TransId
ORDER BY JE.RefDate, JE.TransId;

Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Issue with a simple FMS
entry.content:
Hello,

Try This !

SELECT $[RDR1.PriceBefDi] * $[RDR1.U_Tariff] / 100

  • Remove .NUMBER → it causes the SQL error.

  • Ensure U_Tariff UDF is type Percent (numeric).

  • Assign this query as FMS to your result UDF (e.g. U_TotalTariff).

  • Set the FMS to auto-refresh when U_Tariff changes.

Regards,
Faraz Maqsud.

entry.title: Re: Need to apply validation to restrict back date billin...
entry.content: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides in-app extensibility via Cloud BAdIs. For your scenario, the most relevant enhancement option is BAdI SD_BILLING_DOCUMENT_CHECK. This allows you to implement custom validation logic before a billing document is created. Triggered during billing document creation from the Billing Due List. You can write logic to compare the billing date with the current system date and raise an error if it's in the past beyond your allowed threshold.  SAP Help Portal explains the Create Billing Documents and its extensibility options
